video.title: Full Stack React & Firebase Tutorial - Build a social media app
video.description:
In this full tutorial course, you will learn how to create a full stack, fully-featured social media application using React, Firebase, Redux, Express, and Material-UI. This intermediate tutorial covers things such as creating a backend REST API server with Node.js and Express, user login and authentication, image uploads, notifications, cloud functions, deploying to Firebase, and much more.

🎥 Course created by Classsed. Check out their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/classsed
🔗Classsed Discord: https://discord.gg/GUuKyQW
🔗Classsed Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/classsed

⭐️ Code ⭐️
Functions code repo: https://github.com/hidjou/classsed-react-firebase-functions
React code repo: https://github.com/hidjou/classsed-react-firebase-client

Email regular expression: https://pastebin.com/f33g85pd
NoImg: https://pixabay.com/vectors/blank-profile-picture-mystery-man-973460/
API Base URL: https://europe-west1-socialape-d081e.cloudfunctions.net/api

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:07:03) Create & Read Data
⌨️ (0:27:56) Express & formatting response
⌨️ (0:42:37) User Registration
⌨️ (1:03:22) Validation & Login Route
⌨️ (1:19:33) Authentication Middleware
⌨️ (1:33:10) Refactoring & Organizing
⌨️ (1:48:46) Image Upload
⌨️ (2:13:45) Add and Get User Profile Details
⌨️ (2:33:15) Getting and Commenting on Post
⌨️ (2:56:38) Like, Unlike and Delete Post
⌨️ (3:25:42) Create and Get Notifications
⌨️ (3:58:11) Finishing up Cloud Functions
⌨️ (4:23:46) Getting Started With React
⌨️ (4:44:01) Post Card Details
⌨️ (5:11:45) Login Form
⌨️ (5:50:36) Signup and Auth State
⌨️ (6:05:16) Redux Setup
⌨️ (6:41:17) Signup and Auth Route
⌨️ (6:56:35) Profile Section
⌨️ (7:19:48) Image Upload
⌨️ (7:31:24) Logout and Edit profile
⌨️ (7:53:60) Navbar Buttons
⌨️ (8:07:60) Like and Unlike Actions
⌨️ (8:39:11) Delete Button
⌨️ (8:57:45) Add Post Component
⌨️ (9:20:19) Post Dialog
⌨️ (9:47:30) Post Dialog Details
⌨️ (10:01:21) Displaying Comments
⌨️ (10:16:29) Submitting comments
⌨️ (10:37:28) User Page
⌨️ (10:54:30) Notifications
⌨️ (11:31:59) Loading Skeletons
⌨️ (11:59:28) Deployment to Firebase

February 15, 2022 Update: note that we cannot update this video. Here are some updates from @FrankJacquette:
- Firebase no longer offers a free tier. You will have to set up an account and provide a credit card to use Firebase functions.
- The current version of Busboy has broken the API described in the video. I recommend modifying your code to use the current version.
- React-router-dom has API-breaking changes since the video was made. I recommend downgrading to version 5.x.
- The instructor will occasionally introduce a bug in his work and repair it later. If your code isn't working, watch a little longer before assuming it's your issue.
- The Redux code as implemented will cause an infinite page refresh loop under some circumstances.  Clearing local storage and reloading the page will bypass this.
- componentWillReceiveProps is deprecated and should be replaced with componentDidUpdate. There are several good pages out there describing how to do this.
- Material UI has gone through a major version release since the video was produced.  While everything in the video will continue to work, the documentation you'll find is for the current version of MUI and will be slightly different. Also, Grid has slightly different parameters.

- 

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Brandon Austin
topLevelComment.text: UPDATE: If you're going through this course now, firebase functions now runs with Node.js v.12 by default. To check if your app is running the latest version of node, head to your code editor and open up the package.json file in your functions folder. Under engines you should see a node version. If you want to update the default version, simply edit the line. If you are running a newer version of node, you can use new and updated features (such as spread). Enjoy!

Using Postman I can hit the backend api/user endpoint and, after setting a token and giving the body of the request a "username": "user1", I can receive the user's credentials. Using Postman I cannot get any response other than 404 when I hit the localhost:3000/user endpoint but my localhost:3000/login and localhost:3000/logout work flawlessly. replies.author: bloob
replies.text: Thank you everyone for the help lol I figured out my issue---I shouldn't have stepped away from my code for so long! For real though to anyone with a similar sounding issue I eventually figured out that after adding new firestore functions to my local setup I never did a "firestore deploy" which hoists all those backend api's up to firebase. Hopefully I can save someone from a similar fate.

1 step - check all code, I had a wrong import of 'db' const path

3 step -  you can add console.log inside promise and check what data is coming from doc.data() and snapshot.data()

topLevelComment.author: Jeffrey Che
topLevelComment.text: a bug I noticed and will hopefully help if any of you run into it too: if you try to like or dislike the scream in the scream dialog (with comments rendered), clicking the like/unlike button will result in ".map is called on undefined." This is because "comments" is undefined. To fix this, in the posts handler on the backend, you need to also get comments in both like and unlike functions and add these comments as an array to the scream data that is sent back as a response. When the scream dialog is first opened, getScream works as it should, getting comments too. Invoking the like button clears the comments as it is not receiving them in the response. Great video otherwise! Helped me learn this stack for my internship.

replies.author: Calvin Heath
replies.text: @Clem * Hi! do you have the code? Im having the same error..! do you have a repo or just the plain function? Thanks!

replies.author: Clem *
replies.text: @Jeffrey Che  Thanks mate for the explanation :) It's working perfectly well now !

replies.author: Jeffrey Che
replies.text: @Clem * so I would look at his functions repo and take that. all you need to do is chain one or two then statements (after the like count is incremented/decremented). First, retrieve the comments collection, where the post id is equal to the post id passed in from the params. Then, take the comments and initialize an empty comments array in our scream data object and push each comment to that array. When you return scream data as the response, it will now have comments within it.

topLevelComment.text: 8:45:56 IMPORTANT: up to date, it is necessary DECLARE A NEW INDEX VARIABLE to handle the index, if you use the same declared variable (above in Like and Unlike) your dispatch in Redux won't work (axios will delete in the database but in the Redux side won't work). You can test it adding a console.log("I have been executed") into the deleteScream action after the dispatch and you check in the console a raised error. Best regards.

replies.author: Nixon
replies.text: I had the same issue....youre right. To solve the issue, change "index" the case DELETE_SCREAM (in dataReducer)  into "let indexDel" and 2 lines below "state.screams.splice(indexDel, 1);" ... this solves the Issue as Johan has described

topLevelComment.author: Rahul Ramesh
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone getting stuck at 8:53:48 with the following:
After deleting a post, the card doesn't get deleted unless you refresh the page. 
If you're encountering this: go to your dataReducer.js and to DELETE_SCREAM case. Change your index variable name from "index" to "indexDel" (or anything you like) in both your variable declaration and splice. This should fix it. Don't know why the variables index don't clash for the instructor. Strange one!

topLevelComment.text: For those who is having issues with " Firebase deploy " , here's my solution , go to search bar on your pc and search for " Windows PowerShell " and run it as administrator , after you do that copy this command " Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned "  and paste it on your " Windows PowerShell " once you done that type letter " a " and hit " Enter " on you keyboard , and you are good to go :D , if you have any troubles with other scripts you can just go back once you finish this script that you are working on and change it to letter " N " in the " Windows PowerShell " as default , thank me later xD

topLevelComment.author: Moti Elbilya
topLevelComment.text:
Followed the first 3 hours, and here my conclusion: 
I totaly respect the author of the tutorial for a 12 hour long lesson, that said, a few issues should be addressed

This tutorial should NOT be followed by beginners (or anyone for that matter) , it has a lot wrong and bad coding practices.


1. The whole cloud functions REST API use in this case is absolutely redundant, the firebase (none admin stuff) should be handled in the front-end side, otherwise just build a node.js server and host it somewhere, and you are totaly missing the point of SERVERLESS....
2. The REST api from the cloud functions is very very slow for any production environment.
3.  Why using the Image upload on a cloud function when you can use it storage upload on the front-end ???
4. fileName.split(".")[fileName.split(".").length -1 ]   (Why use the same execution twice instead saving the split result?)
5. using a global variable for a token is a bad idea , you cloud pass it around with the promise response..
6. Using condition with "return myCondition ? true: false" will be the same if you write "return myCondition"

topLevelComment.author: Sam Heyman
topLevelComment.text:
This is a very good video but it's more of a hacking demo rather than a tutorial. The key developer skills necessary to work in a team (and get a job) are not conveyed, in particular:
- small, incremental git commits, with clear messages (to allow for code reviews)
- testing (unit tests and functional tests) to prevent code from breaking as it grows and other developers join
- design choices, API endpoints, db schema and architecture should be decided before you start coding (and placed in a  design document) rather than decided on the fly while you code.
Also in pure REST API, the POST class and GET classes should go to the same endpoint `/classes` which is the resource, not to separate `/class` and `/classes` endpoints (all endpoints should be defined in the design doc before you start coding).
Again great video to understand how React and Firebase work, but coding like this in a job would not be good and as a tutorial this should be clearly indicated.

On giving firebase serve command in terminal it says,  
Your requested "node" version "8" doesn't match your global version "12" 
How to solve this ??

replies.author: Oscar Arnoldo Barrios Corona
replies.text:
Copy to package.json :

"name": "functions",
  "description": "Cloud Functions for Firebase",
  "scripts": {
    "serve": "firebase serve --only functions",
    "shell": "firebase functions:shell",
    "start": "npm run shell",
    "deploy": "firebase deploy --only functions",
    "logs": "firebase functions:log"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": "8"
  },
Then npm install.

replies.author: Richard Vogt Jr.
replies.text: In your package.json file in the functions directory, change the "8" to "12"

replies.author: Elidor Varosi
replies.text: @Neil T Government always tebd to use paid distributions like Red Hat. However start with Ubuntu which is great, stable and has support for any programming thing(expect Visual Studio, but VS code is available thankfully). For gaming activate Proton in Steam and you'll be good to go

replies.author: Neil T
Elidor Varosi
replies.text: @Neil T Linux is safer cause of its architecture. In Windows, you can do everything as an admin, but in Linux, you have to give permission for any new administrative change(like installing apps or changing system rules). Definitely, Linux is much faster in compiling task and that makes it really good for programming, and the, manual control that it gives to the user is just great. However, if you are an artist just stay with Windows because Adobe is not going to support Linux Distros soon. If you don't like using terminal also don't even think about switching your environment. Linux is not just safer, Linux is a great development OS, a really stable one that will even get OS updates without restarting your computer.  Try it if you are a programmer, but wait a few years if you use your PC for gaming or Photo or video editing
